content.user_title: Configure and use UnoCSS atomic CSS
content.value_statement: UnoCSS is an instant atomic CSS engine that provides a flexible, extensible alternative to Tailwind CSS. This skill helps developers configure UnoCSS, write custom utility rules, and leverage presets like Wind, Icons, and Attributify.
actual_capabilities: Provide UnoCSS configuration guidance for uno.config.ts files
Explain utility rules, shortcuts, and dynamic rules for custom CSS generation
Describe theme configuration for colors, breakpoints, and design tokens
Document preset options including Wind3, Wind4, Icons, Attributify, and Typography
Detail transformer features like @apply directives, variant grouping, and JSX support
Explain integrations with Vite and Nuxt frameworks
limitations: This is a reference skill that provides documentation guidance - it does not write or modify code files
Does not install or configure UnoCSS in projects automatically
Cannot execute UnoCSS build processes or validate configurations
Limited to providing information based on UnoCSS documentation and best practices

best_practices: Use the uno.config.ts file format for best IDE support, TypeScript hints, and hot module replacement
Start with a preset (like presetWind3 for Tailwind compatibility) and add customizations progressively
Define custom shortcuts for frequently used class combinations to keep HTML clean and maintainable
Use the safelist option sparingly - prefer extracting utilities from source code when possible
anti_patterns: Avoid putting too many utility classes directly in HTML - use shortcuts and custom rules instead
Do not use the full safelist as a replacement for proper utility extraction configuration
Avoid deeply nested custom rules that could conflict with preset utilities - test combinations
Do not ignore the extracting configuration - proper extraction significantly reduces CSS bundle size

faq.question: What is the difference between UnoCSS and Tailwind CSS?
faq.answer: UnoCSS is a superset of Tailwind CSS syntax, meaning all valid Tailwind classes work. UnoCSS is designed to be instant (faster build times) and fully configurable - you can replace all default utilities with your own. Unlike Tailwind, UnoCSS has no mandatory dependencies and the core is un-opinionated.

faq.question: Which preset should I choose for my project?
faq.answer: Use presetWind3 for projects migrating from Tailwind CSS or Windi CSS. Use presetWind4 for new projects wanting modern CSS features. Use presetMini for minimal bundles or when building custom preset configurations from scratch.

faq.question: How does UnoCSS handle purging and tree-shaking?
faq.answer: UnoCSS automatically extracts used utilities from your source files during build time. Configure the content array in your config to specify which files to scan. Unused utilities are not included in the final CSS, keeping bundles small.

faq.question: Can I use UnoCSS with React, Vue, or other frameworks?
faq.answer: Yes, UnoCSS works with any framework. Use the Vite integration for most modern frameworks (React, Vue, Svelte) or the Nuxt module for Nuxt applications. UnoCSS generates a virtual CSS module that integrates with any build system.

faq.question: How do I create custom responsive variants?
faq.answer: Define custom variants in the variants configuration using the matcher function. Variants allow you to create custom prefix selectors like 'dark:', 'container:', or your own project-specific variants that apply conditional styling.

faq.question: What are transformers and when should I use them?
faq.answer: Transformers modify source code before UnoCSS processes it. Use transformerDirectives for @apply syntax, transformerVariantGroup for grouping utilities, and transformerAttributifyJSX for JSX attributify mode. They improve developer experience but add processing overhead.
